segments.key_quote: In the modern civilization, people think industries are generating many jobs, increasing the wealth of the nation, increasing the GDP and giving so many nice gadgets and facilities and machines for peoples. But actually, there is the negative side of this industrial development.
segments.summary: This segment discusses Queen Kunti's prayers to Krishna for prosperity and contrasts it with the speaker's view on modern industrial development and its negative consequences.
segments.transcript: In this session, we will be discussing from the fortieth verse of the eighth chapter of the first canto of Srimad Bhagavatam, continuing the prayers by Queen Kunti, Ime Janapada Sriddha Supak Kau Shadhi Veerudhaha Vanadrinad Yudanvanto Hedante Tava Bhikshitaihi. The meaning of this verse is all these cities and villages are flourishing in all respects because the herbs and grains are in abundance. The trees are full of fruits, the rivers are flowing, the hills are full of minerals, and the oceans full of wealth. And this is all due to your glancing over them. Kunti is offering prayers to Krishna because of Krishna's glance, there is prosperity, abundance of everything. So Srila Prabhupada explains in the purport, "Even prosperity flourishes by natural gifts and not by gigantic industrial enterprises." In the modern civilization, people think industries are generating many jobs, increasing the wealth of the nation, increasing the GDP and giving so many nice gadgets and facilities and machines for people. But actually, there is the negative side of this industrial development. So many problems due to these industries, which are not generally highlighted or discussed by the industrialists themselves, just like the waste generated, the pollution. So, there is a negative side of this industrial development.

segments.summary: This segment elaborates on the dangers of exploiting material nature and emphasizes the importance of accepting nature's gifts with God consciousness.

segments.key_quote: When sincere souls try to become Krishna's devotees, Krishna very kindly comes before them in his full opulence and glances upon them and they become happy and beautiful.
segments.summary: This segment describes how God's creation provides sufficiently and how cooperation between living beings leads to prosperity, emphasizing the importance of Krishna's glance and devotional service.

segments.key_quote: Simply by Krishna's glance, matter becomes agitated. And then becomes pregnant and gives birth to the living entities.
segments.summary: This segment explains how Krishna's glance is responsible for the creation of the material world and the birth of all living entities, referencing scriptures to support this point.
segments.transcript: This is a fact, cent percent fact. Similarly, the whole material creation is due to Krishna. It is due to Krishna's glance. This is what the scriptures tell us, sa aikshata, this is the statement in the Upanishads. Sa aikshata sa asrujata, this is the statement of the Upanishads. In the Vedas, it is said that he glanced over matter thus agitating it. And there was a creation, the whole creation took place. Simply by Krishna's glance, matter becomes agitated. And then becomes pregnant and gives birth to the living entities. Krishna injects the living entities into the womb of material nature. tasmin garbham dadamyaham, Krishna says in the Bhagavad Gita. It is simply by Krishna's glance that plants, trees, animals and all of the living entities come forth. How is this possible? None of us can say simply by glancing over my wife, I can make her pregnant. Not possible for us. Although this is impossible for us, it is not impossible for Krishna. The Brahma Samhita says, angani yasya sakalendriya vritti manti. What does this mean? It means every part of Krishna's body has all the capabilities of all the other parts of his body. With our eyes, we can only see. But Krishna merely by seeing can make others pregnant. There is no need of sex. For simply by glancing, Krishna can create pregnancy. In Bhagavad Gita, Krishna says in the 9th chapter, 10th verse, maya dhyakshena prakriti hi suyatesu characharam. By my supervision, material nature gives birth to all moving and non-moving living beings. The word aksha means ice. So akshena indicates that all living entities take birth because of the Lord's glance.
